Sups, you assume that in non flipped classrooms teachers stand in front of the classroom and talk.  This is not what good teachers, expert teachers do.  Expert teachers manage classroom time so as to blend group work, teacher input, interaction between teacher and whole class, hands-on, assigning short problems to be solved immediately etc.
As for Asia, students go to school during the day and academic centers at night (basically, 12-18 hours of school). ANYONE who goes to school that much sure as heck better get top test scores!

Everyone loves to gush about Finland, but remember: Finland lets the kids pretty much play outside until 7, and after that, there is little to no homework until they are older. Not at all like the homework load we have in the US today. They go to school all day (not this silly 6 hour day that doesn't work for working parents) and have ample time for lunch and recess--not the crazy 19 minute lunches I remember from my highschool days in America!

If we truly want to emulate the Finnish, we need to back off of the early academics, high homework loads, short school days, and little to no recess time.

Ever hear of the Hawthorne effect? Change gets people excited and initially makes them work harder and do better.

So here, it amounts to this: what we're doing isn't working for these kids, but the novelty of something quite different wakes them up and helps for a while. Since the grades and test scores haven't changed all that much, a change in attitude seems the most likely explanation for the improvements seen here.

After a couple of years, flipping back may well produce the same small good improvements.

I doubt that Finland and Singapore have the educational successes they have from letting students go home and watch 6-minute videos. There's no substitute for teachers who know their subject and who are trained to work with kids of the level they teach -- both learning how the kids think and on how to manage a classroom. There's no substitute for classes small enough to allow for interaction and dealing with individual students. Maybe someday technology will make all of this happen. But we aren't there yet, and claiming that we are doesn't make it true.

Kim, I think your comment is spot on.  The advanced learner enjoys engaging with the teacher during lecture and will often ask questions that explore the material beyond just what's in the homework.  Perhaps there should be some flipped days (for kids who might not otherwise complete homework) and also some more traditional lecture/class discussion days.

"Gun background check supporters submit 250,000 signatures

The campaign got to the 250,000 hurdle through a combination of paid signature gatherers and an “unprecedented grass roots petition distribution effort,” according to a news release.

If Initiative 594 qualifies, it will first go to the state Legislature in 2014. If lawmakers don’t adopt the measure, it will go on the November 2014 ballot."
